content.text: Bash top Command - Display Linux Tasks
Using the top Command
The top command is used to display Linux tasks.
content.html: The top command is used to display Linux tasks.

content.text: It's a powerful tool for monitoring system performance in real-time.

content.text: Understanding the Output
The top command output consists of several columns, each representing different aspects of the system's processes:
content.html: The top command output consists of several columns, each representing different aspects of the system's processes:

content.text: Basic Usage
To display Linux tasks, use top :
content.html: To display Linux tasks, use top:

content.code_html:
top
  PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
 1234 user      20   0  123456  12345   1234 S   0.3  0.2   0:01.23 bash
 5678 user      20   0  234567  23456   2345 S   0.5  0.3   0:02.34 python
 9101 user      20   0  345678  34567   3456 S   0.7  0.4   0:03.45 node

content.text: Options
The top command has options to change how it works:
content.html: The top command has options to change how it works:

content.text: Set Update Interval
The -d option allows you to set the time between updates.
content.html: The -d option allows you to set the time between updates.

content.code:
top
-d
5

PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
1234 user      20   0  123456  12345   1234 S   0.3  0.2   0:01.23 bash
content.code_html:
top -d 5
  PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
 1234 user      20   0  123456  12345   1234 S   0.3  0.2   0:01.23 bash

content.text: Monitor Specific PIDs
The -p option allows you to monitor specific PIDs.
content.html: The -p option allows you to monitor specific PIDs.

content.code:
top
-p
1234

PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
1234 user      20   0  123456  12345   1234 S   0.3  0.2   0:01.23 bash
content.code_html:
top -p 1234
  PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
 1234 user      20   0  123456  12345   1234 S   0.3  0.2   0:01.23 bash

content.text: Show Tasks for a Specific User
The -u option allows you to show tasks for a specific user.
content.html: The -u option allows you to show tasks for a specific user.

content.code:

-u user
PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND

content.text: Set Number of Iterations
The -n option allows you to set the number of iterations before top exits.
content.html: The -n option allows you to set the number of iterations before top exits.

content.code:

-n
2

PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
1234 user      20   0  123456  12345   1234 S   0.3  0.2   0:01.23 bash

content.text: Batch Mode Operation
The -b option allows top to run in batch mode, suitable for sending output to other programs or files.
content.html: The -b option allows top to run in batch mode, suitable for sending output to other programs or files.

content.code:

-b -n
1

PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
1234 user      20   0  123456  12345   1234 S   0.3  0.2   0:01.23 bash

  PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND

content.text: Combining Options
Options can be combined to provide more detailed output. For example, top -b -n 1 runs top in batch mode for one iteration.
